items.title: Interstellar comet sheds unusually large particles

featured_image.name: Breakthrough Listen focused technosignature searches on 3I/ATLAS as it neared Earth

items.description:
An interstellar comet that swept past Earth last week is exhibiting behavior that challenges conventional understanding of cometary physics, according to new analyses published by Harvard astrophysicist Avi Loeb. The object, designated 3I/ATLAS, shed unexpectedly large particles as it traveled through the solar system and displayed a rare wobbling jet structure never before observed in a visitor from another star.

In an essay published December 25, Loeb examined the comet's unusual "anti-tail"—a jet of material pointing toward the Sun rather than away from it—and determined that it contains particles significantly larger than typical comet dust[1]. While standard comet tails are dominated by particles around 0.5 microns in radius, the material in 3I/ATLAS's anti-tail measures between 1 and 100 microns, according to Loeb's analysis[2][1]. This size range is necessary to explain how the particles could travel the observed distance of up to 500,000 kilometers toward the Sun without being immediately stopped by solar radiation pressure[3][4][5].

"The observed length of the anti-tail produced by 3I/ATLAS can only be maintained by particles that are considerably larger than typical dust particles," Loeb wrote, adding that such features are difficult to explain using standard comet physics[2][1].

items.title: On a day that 20 wickets fell, England's cowardly approach was an admission of defeat in Melbourne
items.description: Australia's batting order is unsettled, unbalanced and out of form, but it matters little as England throws in the towel and considers the challenge of a Boxing Day Ashes Test all too hard.

items.title: Mother and stepson drift 10 kilometres in Christmas paddleboard mishap
items.description: Police say two holidaymakers are lucky to be alive after being rescued from the cold waters of Port Phillip, south-west of Melbourne, on Christmas Day.

items.title: Poland intercepts Russian plane, reports airspace breaches from Belarus
items.description: Poland has warned several incidents regarding airspace during the holiday season may signal a provocation.

items.title: Zelenskyy speaks with Trump envoys on Christmas peace talks

featured_image.name: Berlin Hosts Talks On Possible Ukraine Ceasefire

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy held a phone conversation with US President Donald Trump's special envoy Steve Witkoff and son-in-law Jared Kushner on Christmas Day, describing the discussions as "very good" and yielding productive ideas for achieving lasting peace in the nearly four-year war with Russia[1][2][3][4][5].

"We are truly working 24/7 to bring closer the end of this brutal Russian war against Ukraine and to make all documents and steps realistic, effective, and reliable," Zelenskyy wrote on social media following the December 25 call[1][3][4]. The Ukrainian president said he discussed "certain substantive details of the ongoing work" and expressed hope that the "Christmas understandings and ideas we discussed will prove useful"[3][4].

The conversation included key Ukrainian officials: Secretary of the National Security and Defense Council Rustem Umerov, Chief of the General Staff Andriy Hnatov, Foreign Minister Andriy Sybiha, First Deputy Foreign Minister Serhiy Kyslytsya, Deputy Head of the Presidential Office Ihor Brusylo, and Presidential Adviser Oleksandr Bevz[1][2][3]. Zelenskyy announced that Umerov would continue discussions with Witkoff and Kushner later the same day[1][2][3][6].

items.title: Man killed by falling tree as three die in floods and mudslides in California
items.description: State authorities have declared a state of emergency in several counties, including Los Angeles.

items.title: US judge blocks deportation of anti-disinformation activist
items.description: A US judge temporarily blocks the Trump administration from detaining a British man over his work combating online hate and disinformation.

items.title: Master Lock Comanche takes Sydney to Hobart lead, with multiple retirements on day one
items.description: Master Lock Comanche takes over from LawConnect late on day one of the Sydney to Hobart, as tough conditions take their toll on the fleet, forcing a number of retirements. Look back at the action in our blog.

items.title: Police name person of interest in search for Hanukkah car arsonist
items.description: Officers in Melbourne's south continue to investigate an arson attack on a car with a Hanukkah decoration in the early hours of Christmas morning.

items.title: Boddington gold mine damaged in out-of-control bushfire
items.description: The bushfire remains uncontained and out of control, and has burnt through nearly 3,700 hectares.

items.title: Trump launches strikes against Islamic State militants in Nigeria
items.description: Donald Trump says he ordered a "powerful and deadly strike against ISIS terrorist scum" for targeting Christians at levels not seen for years.

items.title: Thailand, Cambodia resume military talks as border conflict death toll hits 96

featured_image.name: US Urges Cambodia and Thailand to End Weeks of Deadly ...

items.description:
Thailand and Cambodia resumed military negotiations on Christmas Day as their border conflict entered its 18th day, with the death toll reaching 96 and nearly one million people displaced across both nations. The secretary-level talks, held under observation of an ASEAN monitoring team, represent the first direct military dialogue since hostilities erupted on December 7-8[1][2][3].

US Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Thursday urged both countries to implement the Kuala Lumpur Peace Accords signed in October, reiterating President Donald Trump's desire for peace during a call with Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet[1][2][3]. "Secretary Rubio further reaffirmed that the United States is prepared to facilitate discussions to ensure peace and stability between Cambodia and Thailand," the State Department said[1][2].

items.title: Kim Jong Un vows five more years of missile development

featured_image.name: Xi Jinping Holds Talks With Kim Jong Un In Beijing

items.description:
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un signaled the country will continue to develop missiles over the next five years during visits to major munitions facilities in late 2025, state media reported on Friday, as the nation prepares for a key party congress that will outline its strategic direction through 2030.

Kim emphasized that "the missile and shell manufacturing sector is crucial for enhancing our war deterrent," according to the Korean Central News Agency[1][2][3]. During his inspections of major munitions enterprises in the final quarter of 2025, Kim ratified draft documents aimed at modernizing key munitions factories, which are to be presented at an important party congress anticipated to occur in early 2026[1][2][4].

The announcement follows Thursday's reveal of Kim overseeing the construction of an 8,700-ton nuclear-powered submarine with his daughter, who is viewed as a potential successor, and the test-firing of long-range surface-to-air missiles[2][5][6]. The submarine project is part of the ruling party's effort to modernize North Korea's navy, one of five key policies the party is pushing to develop the nation's defense capabilities, KCNA said[7][8].

items.title: Christmas celebrations around the world in photos
items.description: From Bethlehem to Beijing, people around the world have been celebrating Christmas in their own traditional way.

items.title: China rejects Pentagon claim on border de-escalation with India

featured_image.name: Pentagon report: China seeks to capitalise on easing LAC ...

items.description:
China on Thursday sharply criticized a US Pentagon report that assessed Beijing is using reduced border tensions with India to prevent deeper strategic alignment between New Delhi and Washington, calling the analysis a distortion intended to justify American military dominance.

Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian responded to the December 23 Pentagon assessment at a regular press briefing in Beijing, stating that the report "distorts China's defense policy, sows discord between China and other countries, and aims at finding a pretext for the U.S. to maintain its military supremacy"[1][2][3][4][5][6]. Lin emphasized that China views its relationship with India "from a strategic height and a long-term perspective" and said the boundary question remains strictly bilateral[1][2][7][8]. "China opposes relevant country's groundless and irresponsible comments," he added[1].

items.title: Scientists stabilize fullerene molecules for safer EV batteries

featured_image.name: Battery breakthrough unlocks secrets to more EV range ...

items.description:
Researchers at Tohoku University have developed a covalently bridged fullerene framework that could enable faster-charging, longer-lasting electric vehicle batteries by solving a stability problem that has long hindered the use of carbon-based materials in energy storage[1][2][3].

The team, led by Distinguished Professor Hao Li at the Advanced Institute for Materials Research, created a compound called Mg4C60 that uses covalent connections between fullerene molecules to prevent the structural collapse that typically occurs when these materials are used in battery anodes[1][2]. The findings were published in the Journal of the American Chemical Society on December 11, with the breakthrough announced publicly on December 23[1][2].

items.title: Trump confirms military will strike land targets in Latin America

featured_image.name: President Trump, With Secretaries Of Navy And War, Makes An Announcement From His Mar-a-Lago Resort In Florida

items.description:
U.S. President Donald Trump confirmed on Christmas Eve that the military will begin conducting strikes on land targets in Latin America to combat drug cartels, marking a potential escalation from the maritime campaign that has killed at least 105 people since September[1][2][3].

Speaking from his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida during a holiday address to U.S. troops, Trump claimed that maritime drug smuggling has been reduced by 96 percent[1][2][4]. "Now we're going after the land," Trump said, adding that land operations would be "easier" than the maritime interdictions[1][2]. The president extended special congratulations to the crew of the USS Gerald R. Ford, currently deployed in the Caribbean[1][2].

items.title: Ukraine delivers US-backed peace plan to Russia

featured_image.name: Ukraine hands revised 20-point peace plan proposal to US, ABC News reports

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy presented a revised 20-point peace proposal on December 23 after weeks of negotiations with US officials, offering potential pathways to end the nearly four-year war with Russia—even as Moscow launched deadly drone strikes on Christmas night that killed at least two people[1][2].

The plan, developed jointly by Ukrainian and American negotiators, includes NATO-style security guarantees and proposes demilitarized zones in eastern Ukraine, according to Zelenskyy's presentation to journalists in Kyiv[2][3][4]. The framework was formally delivered to Russian President Vladimir Putin's government on December 24, though the Kremlin has given no indication it will accept the terms[2][3].

items.title: Nvidia agrees to buy Groq assets for $20B

featured_image.name: Groq more than doubles valuation to $6.9 billion as investors bet on AI chips

items.description:
Nvidia has agreed to acquire assets from AI chip startup Groq for approximately $20 billion in cash, according to a CNBC report, marking the semiconductor giant's largest transaction ever as it moves to cement its dominance in the rapidly expanding artificial intelligence hardware market[1][2][3]. The deal, announced December 24, brings Groq's specialized inference chip technology and top engineering talent under Nvidia's control while the startup continues operating independently[1][4].

Under the arrangement, Groq founder and CEO Jonathan Ross—a former Google engineer who helped develop the company's Tensor Processing Unit—will join Nvidia along with President Sunny Madra and other key staff members[1][5][6]. Simon Edwards, currently Groq's finance chief, will assume the CEO role as the company maintains its cloud business, GroqCloud[1][4][7].

items.title: Ukraine reports deadly Russian drone strikes into Christmas morning
items.description: Russia launched 131 drones overnight, Ukraine's air force said.

items.title: Pope Leo XIV highlights Gaza crisis in first Christmas Mass

featured_image.name: Pope Leo laments suffering of Gaza Palestinians in first Christmas ...

items.description:
Pope Leo XIV used his inaugural Christmas Mass as pontiff to draw attention to Palestinians sheltering in Gaza, marking an unusually direct appeal on a day traditionally reserved for solemn spiritual reflection[1][2][3].

Presiding over the Christmas Day service at St. Peter's Basilica before thousands of worshippers, the first American pope invoked the story of Jesus's birth in a stable to reference the humanitarian crisis facing displaced Gazans. "How, then, can we not think of the tents in Gaza, exposed for weeks to rain, wind and cold?" Leo asked, referring to God having "pitched his fragile tent" among humanity[1][2][3][4].

The 69-year-old Chicago native, who was elected in May following Pope Francis's death, also lamented conditions for homeless populations worldwide and condemned the destruction wrought by global conflicts. "Fragile is the flesh of defenseless populations, tried by so many wars, ongoing or concluded, leaving behind rubble and open wounds," he said[1][3][4]. He criticized "the falsehoods that fill the pompous speeches of those who send them to their deaths" regarding young soldiers forced into combat[2][3].

items.title: Turkey begins black box analysis of jet crash that killed Libyan military chief
items.description: The Turkish Ministry of Defense says the technical analysis of black boxes from a jet crash that killed eight people, including Libya’s military chief, has begun.

items.title: Algeria votes to declare French colonization a crime and demands restitution
items.description: Algerian legislators have declared France's colonization a crime, demanding restitution for property taken during its 130-year rule.

items.title: Rescue mission helicopter crashes on Mount Kilimanjaro, killing all 5 on board
items.description: Five people have died after a helicopter crashed on Africa’s highest mountain, Mount Kilimanjaro, in Tanzania.

items.title: Somalis vote in the first one-person, one-vote local election in decades
items.description: Residents of Somalia’s capital are set to vote in a controversial local election that marks the country’s first-ever one-person, one-vote poll since 1969.

items.title: Saudi Arabia calls on Yemen separatists to leave 2 governorates as coalition strains
items.description: Saudi Arabia has called on separatists in Yemen to withdraw from two governorates they now hold.

items.title: Albanese announces bravery award for heroes of Bondi antisemitic attack
items.description: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced a national bravery award to honor those who confronted an antisemitic terror attack.

items.title: North Korea displays apparent progress in construction of nuclear-powered submarine
items.description: North Korea displayed apparent progress in the construction of a nuclear-powered submarine, with state media photos showing a largely completed hull as leader Kim Jong Un condemned rival South Korea’s push to acquire the technology.

items.title: Zelenskyy says he's open to creating demilitarized zone in Ukraine's industrial heartland
items.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says he would be willing to withdraw troops from the country’s eastern industrial heartland as part of a plan to end Russia’s war, if Moscow also pulls back and the area becomes a demilitarized zone monitored by international forces.

items.title: Blast at mosque in Nigeria kills 5 and injures more than 30 in apparent suicide attack
items.description: A bomb has exploded during prayers at a mosque in Nigeria's northeastern city of Maiduguri, killing five people.
